text: The first generation of pokemon games is a funny little corolary to the current state of US Politics and Political Parties... (Colors are on point) Red and Blue versions were nearly identical in every way, with very few minor differences in the available pokemon. However, gameplay was identical, so were the glitches. And everyone had 1 favorite version they stood by (mine was blue version) but the reality was we all cheated the same and exploited the same glitches to win. Yellow version came out later, and provided the same conceptual style, but added major changes to the story and plotline, as well as significant changes to game play. But most importantly, in Yellow Version you had to win without exploiting the same glitches that made Blue and Red so easy. The developers patched it to make Yellow Version have a much harder path to the same win.  Blue Version and Red Version could still link with and compete against Yellow version players, but they still had access to infinite rare candies and other Items to make for an uneven playing field.   Yellow Version was easilly the best of Gen 1, because while it was certainly harder, it was a much more rewarding experience to win with it, knowing you had an uphill battle that the other kids at summer camp were cheating to beat.  Don't play Blue and Red Versions, play Yellow Version and vote Libertarian.

4/20 is a fun day of celebration for most of the country. But this year it fell on the culmimation of Patriots Day Weekend. Patriots Day is a holiday not celebrated by most of the country, but has a place of great prestige in Massachusetts, remembering the Battle of Concord and Lexington, and the begining of the American Revolution.  In a normal year, Patriots Day Weekend is capped off with Marathon Monday, the traditional running of the Boston Marathon, an iconic race through the Heart of Boston, bringing Thousands of runners, and Hundreds of thousands of spectators lining the course from Hopkinton to Boston to cheer them on.  However, this is not a typical year. The Boston Marathon was cancelled this year, which is a striking blow to both the small businesses on the route that depend on the days traffic, as well as the heart and soul of the greater Boston Area as a whole.  This isn't the first time in my life that the Marathon has been atypical. 7 years ago, on Patriots Day, I was serving in the Massachusetts National Guard and had volunteered to work security for the 2013 Boston Marathon. That was not a typical marathon, and the following days shook the very foundations of the Liberty and Freedom we were celebrating. It began a cascade of events that drastically changed my life, and my outlook on Liberty and freedom.  That series of events led to my inevitably getting involved with the Libertarian Party, running for office, and working tirelessly to protect the freedoms we hold so dear.  Please read the article I linked that I wrote and published last year, and please take a moment to like and share my page, and in these trying times, if you can spare it, visit www.odonnell2020.com/donate to help contribute to a campaign to bring a new voice to the political discussion in the US Senate. https://medium.com/@ODonnell4NH/why-im-running-as-a-libertarian-402be6e52575 .

Social distancing and self quarantine might be good ideas to minimize exposure to pathogens, but these orders set a dangerous precedent for government overreach.  Tyrants have historically used emergencies to grant themselves new far reaching powers that never go away once the situation has resolved. It is incumbent upon us to be vigilant not only for our health, but for the preservation of our liberties as well.

What Orwell feared were those who would ban books. What Huxley feared was that there would be no reason to ban books, for there would be no one who would want to read one. Orwell feared those who would deprive us of information. Huxley feared those who would give us so much that we would be reduced to passivity and egotism.  In "Nineteen Eighty-Four" people are controlled by inflicting pain. In "A Brave New World" people are controlled by inflicting pleasure.  In short, Orwell feared that what we hate will ruin us. And Huxley feared that what we love will ruin us.  What I fear is that they were both right and we have ruined ourselves.

When I first ran for a position on the Libertarian National Committee, it was out of a place of frustration. I was unhappy with the actions of some members of the Committee, and what I saw as a bad direction for the Libertarian Party. After the past 2 terms on the LNC, I could not be happier with the group of people I've gotten to work with, and am extremely proud of the progress we have made in growing the Libertarian Party.  The past term especially, we've seen traditional caucus lines dissolve, and ideological differences put aside as the members committee doubled efforts time and again to do what needed to be done to increase fundraising, grow membership, and ensure a positive future for Libertarians across the Country. As a member of the committee, Joe Bishop-Henchman has been a crucial key player in this positive growth. While I have chosen not to seek a 3rd term as the Region 8 Representative, I'm confident that under the leadership of Joe, the Libertarian Party can continue its historic growth.  Joe comes to the table with experience in running and growing a non profit advocacy group on a national scale, and has the skills and temperament to be a fantastic leader moving forward. In his time on the LNC he has championed meticulous transparency, and an undeniable commitment to keeping membership both informed and involved with the activities of the LNC. I'm happy to endorse him as Chair of the National Libertarian Party.

source: Justin O'Donnell for U.S. Senate,Libertarian Party of New Hampshire
text: In half of one week we witnessed a possibly rigged election from one party and a complete abandonment of constitutional duty from the other.  All in the struggle to maintain power over the other.  Are you ready to ditch the duopoly yet?

I will not be participating in the New Hampshire Presidential Primary as a voter.  Since the State of New Hampshire does not recognize The Libertarian Party as a political party, my official political party registration is "unenrolled" which allows me to take advantage of the semi-open primaries in NH, and vote in the Presidential preference Primary of whichever party I choose.  I have been mulling the consideration of this for the past few weeks, and listening to arguments for what Libertarians should do from a number of people, all with the best intentions. Some Argue that we should pull Republican Ballots to vote for a candidate other than Trump, in order to send a message to the establishment that there is dissent within the right. Some have argued that we should pull Democrat Ballots, and vote for Tulsi Gabbard to show support for an anti-war voice in a field of foreign policy hawks.  Some have Argued that we should pull Democrat Ballots and vote for Biden, to shore up his win in the Dem Primary, and hasten the coming of a General Election between two universally disliked candidates once again, in order to best position the Libertarian Nominee.  In my reflection I've decided that all of these approaches are simply taking steps to waste my vote.  In 2016, Gary Johnson answered the claims of voting for him being a waste by saying "The only wasted vote, is a vote cast for someone you don't believe in."  Well, here in 2020, there is not a single candidate in the Primary of either Major party who I believe represents me, or my values. So on principle, I will not waste my vote by casting it. I will not participate in an effort to influence the nomination process of an organization for which I am not a member or a supporter. I will go to work, I will go about my day, and then In May, I will cast my vote as a delegate to The Libertarian National Convention, for a Candidate who I believe in. In the meantime, I will continue to build my team for our upcoming campaign for US Senate, and take the steps necessary to provide an alternative for New Hampshire Voters come November. You can help me with that by visiting www.odonnell2020.com/donate today, and making your contribution, to helping us Bring a New Voice, to New Hampshire!

Our first goal is to get on the ballot. Before we can do anything else, we have to succeed at this monumental task. Because the State of New Hampshire does not recognize The Libertarian Party, we need to collect 3,000 valid signatures of Registered voters in order to be allowed to file for the General Election.  Petition Drives aren't easy, but they are a great opportunity to kick-start a campaign and build name recognition. But they also take resources, time, volunteers, and money. The average cost per signature in 2016 was $4, So that's our first milestone goal to reach!  Will you help us out today by heading over to www.odonnell2020.com/donate and contributing to our efforts to bring new choices to the voters in new Hampshire?

Last night I was proud to have been nominated and endorsed by The Libertarian Party of New Hampshire to seek the office of United States Senate in the 2020 Election. When I ran for Congress in 2018, I was able to simply file with the Secretary of State to get my name on the Ballot by paying a small fee. Unfortunately, the circumstances have changed, and the rules are stacked against us.  Following the 2018 Elections, the Libertarian Party of New Hampshire lost their status as a recognized major political party with the New Hampshire Secretary of State. In order to get on the ballot in 2020, we're going to have to do it the old fashioned way, the hard way, the expensive way.  In order to get on the ballot in 2020, we need to collect 3,000 Valid signatures from registered voters across New Hampshire. This is going to take time, effort, and money. Historically, these petition drives have cost as much as $8 per signature! But with a strong core group of volunteers, help from the Libertarian Party of New Hampshire, and our experience from past petition drives, we're confident we can get it done for less than half of that! Furthermore, our effort with this petition drive will help not just me, but all Libertarian Candidates in New Hampshire get on the general election ballot in November 2020!  Can I count on your help today, so we can hit the ground running next year?  Every $4 donated gets 1 signature! Your Contribution of $40 today ensures that we get 10 signatures closer to being on the ballot!  www.odonnell2020.com/donate Head over to our page to donate today, and make sure to share our movement with your family and friends!

source: Justin O'Donnell for U.S. Senate,Aeris Stewart
text: Migrant children are wasting away in internment camps and being forcibly separated from their families.  The War on Drugs continues to terrorize communities of color, keeping people in a vicious cycle of incarceration and poverty.  Ideologically-motivated violence, like the mass shooting in El Paso, is seemingly on the rise and, as a result, many people on both sides of the aisle are calling for laws that would continue to weaken our right to self defense.  Libertarianism is more than an economic philosophy, more than a tax cut or a balanced budget. It’s a philosophy that understands that our right to personal and economic liberty is innate to our humanity, not something granted by popular vote.  When social issues pose the greatest threat to individual liberty, libertarians need to be at the forefront of political change. We need to speak up. We need to hold the establishment accountable as best we can.  If that seems too much to ask, maybe we should go home and quit the Liberty Movement. We don’t need to waste our energy compromising; the Republicans and Democrats will do that for us just enough.

source: Justin O'Donnell for U.S. Senate,John Jay Myers
text: This post is not a defense of Trump, or an endorsement of Governor Sanford. But this post should be seen as an indictment of outrage culture, and the fact that our media cares more about ratings and confirmation bias than reporting the news.Former Governor Sanford was on CNN yesterday, they asked him what he thought of Trumps comments and he said they were bad, however "I am here to talk about how our interest payments on our debt will soon be higher than what we spend on National Defense"... The CNN anchor said "Yes, well what about the comments Trump made?" Sanford said a lot of this is political theater and certainly there is no shortage of people talking about it, but who is talking about the fact that we are paying more in interest on our debt then our bloated defense budget?  CNN "Sir if we could get back to Trumps remarks, do you believe they are racist?"  This ladies and gentlemen... is the problem. Trump's comments were inflammatory even racist... and he is a giant douche bag... but it's not those comments that are going to have every American eating out of garbage cans in a couple of years.  If Trump or CNN would talk about that, that would be neat.  I say we just say fuck the debt... and get one of those deals where our credit sucks for the next 7 years.

In 1973, a bi-partisan congressional commission recommended to the White House broad reforms, including decriminalization of drugs, as scientific evidence had shown that Marijuana was not as dangerous as it was reported, and that decriminalization and harm reduction would do more to solve problems of drug use than law enforcement.  Rather than take that advice, the Nixon Administration doubled down and launched the War on Drugs in order to bully their political enemies and minorities.  Nixon's own aide has outright admitted this.  "We knew we couldn't make it illegal to be either against the war or black, but by getting the public to associate hippies with Marijuana and Blacks with Heroin, and then criminalizing both heavily, we could disrupt those communities. We could arrest their leaders, raid their homes, break up their meetings, and vilify them night after night on the evening news. Did we know we were lying about the drugs? Of course we did."  -John Ehrlichman  White House Domestic Affairs Advisor 1969-1973

text: I'm running for US Senate in New Hampshire to spread the Ideas of Personal Liberty and Individual Freedom. I'm striving to break out of the mold for the 2 party system that cares more about power than they do about People. And I can't do it without your Help.  We need your help to do a number of things, Get ballot access, get on the debate stage, and advertise our campaign to every last voter in New Hampshire.  Unfortunately, all of these things cost money, even the ones that shouldn't. In order to get on the Ballot we need to Spend between $12-$15,000 on petition signatures for a state wide petition drive.  In order to be in the debates, we need to raise at least the $25,000 that WMUR and Hearst Media Group set as the bar for debate inclusion in 2018.  In order to poll well enough to be noticed, we need to be advertising, and touring the state, which means at least $40,000 for signs, ads, outreach and events. I can't do any of this, without your help!  Can I count on you today to visit www.odonnell2020.com/donate to make your contribution towards changing the Political Narrative in New Hampshire?  $25 gets us 5 Signatures! $50 gets us 5 Yard Signs! $250 helps us Hold a town hall event to meet with voters! $2500 gets us 10% of the way to the debate stage! Today is the Parliamentary Elections in Benin. Previously there were 28 political parties represented in Parliament. The two parties that held the majority of seats formed a coalition, and passed new restrictive ballot access laws, and consolidated power by eliminating all opposition parties from the ballot. Instead of 28 choices on their ballot, today people in Benin have only 2. Journalists and academics are talking about how terrible it is, amd how it is a huge blow to African Democracy, and how the silencing of minority parties and oppoaition voices is a dangerous abuse of authority and a move towards dictatorship... Partisan politics is tearing our Nation's Capitol apart. Republicans and Democrats have spent more time attacking each other than working to serve the interests of their constituents. The controversy surrounding the President and vague assertions of 'collusion' have distracted everyone from the important business they were elected to conduct. The preliminary release of minor details from the Special Counsel's report has both sides claiming vindication, and the American People being forgotten again.  It's time we cast aside the disastrous two-party system, and fight for real change, for real fiscal responsibility, and real integrity in Washington. Join us today by making a monthly pledge to stand up to the status quo, and give New Hampshire voters the chance to choose a strong, independent, libertarian voice to represent them in DC in 2020.  It's time to elect politicians who will put their differences aside, and work together to serve the American People. It's time we work diligently towards ending our failed war on drugs, ending our foreign wars, and restoring faith in the American Economy through free and open trade! Help us send a Message to the US Senate, that its time for real change, and time to try something different! Join us today, and let's make O'Donnell 2020 a revolutionary campaign in New Hampshire! When the decision is left to people, their inherent biases come forward in the form of state oppression and the deprivation of rights and liberty.  https://www.cato.org/blog/atf-attempts-deny-non-binary-trans-americans-guns?fbclid=IwAR17AoVrdQgDESGHVaGdQZLsqefP5mMv5L3Kc3c-nH0KnADJvVtBYhuaPQQ

In 2018 we tried something big, we tried to run a lean and frugal campaign focused on the issues and spreading a message of Liberty in New Hampshire. We were discounted, disregarded, and ignored by the media. Our message was stifled, and our voice was silenced- excluded from the debates, and hushed away as a novelty.  Yet still, almost 7,000 Granite Staters in the 2nd District made their way to the polls on Election day and cast a vote for something different. You, and everyone else who made that conscious decision to cast aside party politics and vote for real change, are why I take pride in what we accomplished against all odds. And you and the support you gave me in 2018, is why I'm planning to do something even bigger in 2020.  2020 will bring us more opportunity, but even more hurdles to climb. We don't have ballot access, so we will need to mount a massive petition drive across the State of New Hampshire to even get on the ballot - this will cost money.  We will have to build our own media presence to counter the muzzle of WMUR and mainstream media in covering our mission - this will cost money.  We will have to travel the entire state, and meet with voters and stakeholders from Nashua to Pittsburg, from Keene to Portsmouth, and from Concord to Dixville Notch - this will cost money.  We will launch a marketing campaign to make sure that every single New Hampshire Voter goes to the polls in 2020 fully aware that I'm running for United States Senate - this will cost money.  We will make a BOLD statement this year, and we will refuse to be silenced and sent off to the corner - this will take your help! What was accomplished in 2018 wasn't my doing alone, I couldn't have done it without the help of each and every person who volunteered, donated, and supported our campaign. "Just because you do not take an interest in politics, doesn't mean politics won't take an interest in you." - Pericles Many in the Liberty movement, and self professed Libertarians and anarchists act as if participation in politics is the problem, and like to speak negatively of those of us who are involved politically.  I don't condemn them for their choice, I just like to remind them that they can ignore the states encroachment all they want, it won't stop or slow it, so it is in their interests to at least support those who work to stop the expansion of the state on their behalf.

Did you know that in 2016, over $40,000 was spent on Ballot access petitioning in New Hampshire for third party and independent candidates? That's over $40,000 that it cost just to get names printed on the ballot so that voters would have another option.  That's a cost that Republicans and Democrats don't have to worry about, because they write the rules to make it easier on themselves. But in 2020, Libertarians, Greens, and Independents will be trying to have their voices heard, and it's gonna be expensive.

Had a very productive day in the state capitol. Networking with state representatives from both major parties and testifying on bills effecting election law.  There appeared to be a theme of tripartisan concern about protecting 3rd party ballot access in the committee today, and for that I'm grateful.  It was a pleasure to make recomendations for amendments to bills that would protect independent and third party camdidates in NH, while simultaneously increasing participation and transparency in our elections, and having representatoves from both major parties express support. Even the deputy Secretary of State acknowledged my points and testified in favor of them.

Tomorrow at 1:30 PM the New Hampshire House Elections law Committee will be hearing HB 643.  On the surface, this bill just changes the date of the Primary from the Tuesday before the first Wednesday in September, to the Tuesday before the first Wednesday in June.  Not only does this shift the primary up 3 months, but it would also shift the filing period, and petition gathering period up 3 months as well. And since Petitions for Independent and minor party candidates are due to the Supervisors of the Checklist for validation by 5pm on the Wednesday 5 weeks prior to the state Primary (RSA 655:41), and since NH has no mechanism for substitution of candidates, It would in effect require organizations like The Libertarian Party and The Green Party and The Constitution Party, who are not recognized as major parties by the State of New Hampshire, to hold their nominating Conventions prior to the new filing period which would begin in early March, rather than early June as it does currently.  Currently, as the Libertarian Party holds their nominating Convention in May of Presidential Years, we are able to petition our candidate onto the ballot in New Hampshire following said convention for 3,000 signatures. However, should this bill pass, the only option for access to the ballot that would be available to third party candidates, would be through an organizational petition starting January 1st, and collecting 17,407 valid signatures prior to the end of March, and submitting a list of nominated candidates afterwards.  I will be testifying against this Bill in Committee Tomorrow Afternoon, but should it pass, it would drastically alter the landscape of Presidential Ballot Access in New Hampshire, and make it significantly harder, and more costly to achieve ballot access in this state for the Libertarian Candidate.

Libertarian Party Platform: 3.4 Free Trade and Migration We support the removal of governmental impediments to free trade. Political freedom and escape from tyranny demand that individuals not be unreasonably constrained by government in the crossing of political boundaries. Economic freedom demands the unrestricted movement of human as well as financial capital across national borders. Read more at www.LP.org/platform
